articles.headline: U.S. and NATO Balk on Troops for Lebanon Force
articles.snippet: Support is building for an international military force in southern Lebanon, but there are concerns that soldiers would be seen as allied to Israel.
articles.abstract: Support is building for an international military force in southern Lebanon, but there are concerns that soldiers would be seen as allied to Israel.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS, July 24 — Support is building quickly for an international military force to be placed in southern Lebanon, but there remains a small problem: where will the troops come from?
articles.byline: By Elaine Sciolino and Steven Erlanger

articles.headline: Trade Talks Fail Over an Impasse on Farm Tariffs
articles.snippet: The collapse of negotiations touched off a bitter new round of recriminations between the United States and Europe.
articles.abstract: The collapse of negotiations touched off a bitter new round of recriminations between the United States and Europe.
articles.lead_paragraph: GENEVA, July 24 — Negotiations aimed at reaching a new global trade agreement collapsed here Monday, touching off a bitter new round of recriminations between the United States and Europe over farm trade barriers and dealing a blow to the Bush administration’s international economic agenda.
articles.byline: By Tom Wright and Steven R. Weisman

articles.headline: Big Drug Makers Post Profits That Beat Forecasts
articles.snippet: A rally in both drug shares and the broader market was fueled as Merck and Schering-Plough reported profits that were well ahead of analysts’ expectations.
articles.abstract: A rally in both drug shares and the broader market was fueled as Merck and Schering-Plough reported profits that were well ahead of analysts’ expectations.
articles.lead_paragraph: The summer revival in the pharmaceutical industry continued as Merck and Schering-Plough, two major American drug makers, reported second-quarter profits yesterday that were well ahead of analysts’ expectations.

articles.headline: Options Brought Riches and Now Big Trouble
articles.snippet: It was stock options that made Gregory L. Reyes, the former chief executive of Brocade Communications Systems, very rich, and now it is abuse of options that may send him to prison.
articles.abstract: It was stock options that made Gregory L. Reyes, the former chief executive of Brocade Communications Systems, very rich, and now it is abuse of options that may send him to prison.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was stock options that made Gregory L. Reyes, the former chief executive of Brocade Communications Systems, very rich, and now it is abuse of options that may send him to prison.

articles.headline: Stem Cell Work Gets States’ Aid After Bush Veto
articles.snippet: Two governors have offered state money for research, and the issue has sprung to the forefront of crucial elections.
articles.abstract: Two governors have offered state money for research, and the issue has sprung to the forefront of crucial elections.

articles.headline: The Gambling Is Virtual; the Money Is Real
articles.snippet: For the first time, Washington has succeeded in temporarily shutting down a publicly owned gambling site, and its effort has operators’ share prices plummeting.
articles.abstract: For the first time, Washington has succeeded in temporarily shutting down a publicly owned gambling site, and its effort has operators’ share prices plummeting.
articles.lead_paragraph: Can the United States handcuff online wagering?
articles.byline: By Matt Richtel and Heather Timmons

articles.headline: HCA Buyout Highlights Era of Going Private
articles.snippet: Taking advantage of relatively cheap borrowing costs, private-equity firms have gone on a shopping spree.
articles.abstract: Taking advantage of relatively cheap borrowing costs, private-equity firms have gone on a shopping spree.
articles.lead_paragraph: In April, investment bankers from Merrill Lynch paid one of their regular visits to HCA, the hospital company. Instead of the usual pitch to sell HCA some more hospitals, the bankers had a more audacious proposal: Assemble a group of private investors to acquire the company for more than $30 billion.

articles.headline: Investigations Are Sifting Good, Bad and Only Ugly
articles.snippet: Last week’s charges against former executives at Brocade were the first in an investigation into the manipulation of stock options. No one expects that they will be the last.
articles.abstract: Last week’s charges against former executives at Brocade were the first in an investigation into the manipulation of stock options. No one expects that they will be the last.
articles.lead_paragraph: Brocade Communications will not be alone.

articles.headline: Border Clashes Intensify as Israel Hunts Militants
articles.snippet: Some of the most intense clashes so far between Israeli troops and Hezbollah militants came as Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice arrived in the region.
articles.abstract: Some of the most intense clashes so far between Israeli troops and Hezbollah militants came as Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice arrived in the region.
articles.lead_paragraph: AVIVIM, Israel, July 24 — In some of the most intense ground clashes so far, Israeli troops and Hezbollah militants fought fiercely Monday in and around two hilltop towns in southern Lebanon where the Israeli military is seeking to drive the militants away from the border.
articles.byline: By Craig S. Smith and Greg Myre

articles.headline: Big Drug Makers Post Profits That Beat Forecasts
articles.snippet: The summer revival in the pharmaceutical industry continued as Merck and Schering-Plough, two major American drug makers, reported second-quarter profits yesterday that were well ahead of analysts' expectations.     Medicare Part D, which offers p...
articles.abstract: The summer revival in the pharmaceutical industry continued as Merck and Schering-Plough, two major American drug makers, reported second-quarter profits yesterday that were well ahead of analysts' expectations.     Medicare Part D, which offers prescription coverage for people over 65, is fueling the profits, as drug makers benefit from new prescriptions and somewhat higher prices for medicines, Wall Street analysts say. The number of prescriptions has risen 3 percent this year, and growth accelerated in June to more than 5 percent, according to a report from Merrill Lynch.
articles.lead_paragraph: The summer revival in the pharmaceutical industry continued as Merck and Schering-Plough, two major American drug makers, reported second-quarter profits yesterday that were well ahead of analysts' expectations.

articles.headline: Trade Talks Fail Over an Impasse on Farm Tariffs
articles.snippet: Negotiations aimed at reaching a new global trade agreement collapsed here Monday, touching off a bitter new round of recriminations between the United States and Europe over farm trade barriers and dealing a blow to the Bush administration's inte...
articles.abstract: Negotiations aimed at reaching a new global trade agreement collapsed here Monday, touching off a bitter new round of recriminations between the United States and Europe over farm trade barriers and dealing a blow to the Bush administration's international economic agenda.     After two days of wrangling by negotiators from six leading trade nations and blocs, the director general of the World Trade Organization, Pascal Lamy, formally suspended the talks, declaring that he no longer had hope of overcoming resistance in wealthy countries to sharply reducing domestic protection for their politically powerful farm industries.
articles.lead_paragraph: GENEVA, July 24 - Negotiations aimed at reaching a new global trade agreement collapsed here Monday, touching off a bitter new round of recriminations between the United States and Europe over farm trade barriers and dealing a blow to the Bush administration's international economic agenda.
articles.byline: By Tom Wrightand Steven R. Weisman

articles.headline: U.S. and NATO Balk Over Lebanon
articles.snippet: Support is building quickly for an international military force to be placed in southern Lebanon, but there remains a small problem: where will the troops come from?      The United States has ruled out its soldiers' participating, NATO says it is...
articles.abstract: Support is building quickly for an international military force to be placed in southern Lebanon, but there remains a small problem: where will the troops come from?      The United States has ruled out its soldiers' participating, NATO says it is overstretched, Britain feels its troops are overcommitted and Germany says it is willing to participate only if Hezbollah, the Lebanese militia that it would police, agrees to it, a highly unlikely development.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS, July 24 - Support is building quickly for an international military force to be placed in southern Lebanon, but there remains a small problem: where will the troops come from?
articles.byline: By Elaine Sciolino and Steven Erlanger

articles.headline: Stem Cell Work Gets States Aid After Bush Veto
articles.snippet: President Bush's veto of legislation to expand federally financed embryonic stem cell research has had the unintended consequence of drawing state money into the contentious field and has highlighted the issue in election campaigns across the coun...
articles.abstract: President Bush's veto of legislation to expand federally financed embryonic stem cell research has had the unintended consequence of drawing state money into the contentious field and has highlighted the issue in election campaigns across the country.     Two governors seized the political moment Thursday, the day after the veto, to raise their ante for stem cell research.

articles.headline: HCA Buyout Highlights Era of Going Private
articles.snippet: In April, investment bankers from Merrill Lynch paid one of their regular visits to HCA, the hospital company. Instead of the usual pitch to sell HCA some more hospitals, the bankers had a more audacious proposal: Assemble a group of private inves...
articles.abstract: In April, investment bankers from Merrill Lynch paid one of their regular visits to HCA, the hospital company. Instead of the usual pitch to sell HCA some more hospitals, the bankers had a more audacious proposal: Assemble a group of private investors to acquire the company for more than $30 billion.     Yesterday, HCA agreed to do just that, to sell itself to three private-equity firms and the family of Senator Bill Frist, the Senate majority leader, whose father, the late Dr. Thomas Frist Sr., and his brother, Dr. Thomas F. Frist Jr., founded HCA.
articles.lead_paragraph: In April, investment bankers from Merrill Lynch paid one of their regular visits to HCA, the hospital company. Instead of the usual pitch to sell HCA some more hospitals, the bankers had a more audacious proposal: Assemble a group of private investors to acquire the company for more than $30 billion.

articles.headline: Options Brought Riches and Now Big Trouble
articles.snippet: It was stock options that made Gregory L. Reyes, the former chief executive of Brocade Communications Systems, very rich, and now it is abuse of options that may send him to prison.     Mr. Reyes faces Justice Department charges that documents wer...
articles.abstract: It was stock options that made Gregory L. Reyes, the former chief executive of Brocade Communications Systems, very rich, and now it is abuse of options that may send him to prison.     Mr. Reyes faces Justice Department charges that documents were forged as part of a scheme to issue backdated stock options, although the criminal charges do not cover options given to him.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was stock options that made Gregory L. Reyes, the former chief executive of Brocade Communications Systems, very rich, and now it is abuse of options that may send him to prison.

articles.headline: The Gambling Is Virtual; the Money Is Real
articles.snippet: Can the United States handcuff online wagering?     Glen Walker, a professional sports bettor in North Carolina who places up to 70 bets a week of $2,000 to $5,000 each during football season, does not think so. ''They're not going to stop the off...
articles.abstract: Can the United States handcuff online wagering?     Glen Walker, a professional sports bettor in North Carolina who places up to 70 bets a week of $2,000 to $5,000 each during football season, does not think so. ''They're not going to stop the offshore sports books,'' Mr. Walker said. A crackdown will ''just force it back to the black market.''
articles.lead_paragraph: Can the United States handcuff online wagering?
articles.byline: By Matt Richtel and Heather Timmons

articles.headline: Investigations Are Sifting Good, Bad and Only Ugly
articles.snippet: Brocade Communications will not be alone.      Last week's civil and criminal charges against former executives at Brocade, a maker of data storage networking products, were the first in a widening investigation into the manipulation of stock opti...
articles.abstract: Brocade Communications will not be alone.      Last week's civil and criminal charges against former executives at Brocade, a maker of data storage networking products, were the first in a widening investigation into the manipulation of stock options. No one expects that they will be the last.
articles.lead_paragraph: Brocade Communications will not be alone.

articles.headline: Border Clashes Intensify as Israel Hunts Militants
articles.snippet: In some of the most intense ground clashes so far, Israeli troops and Hezbollah militants fought fiercely Monday in and around two hilltop towns in southern Lebanon where the Israeli military is seeking to drive the militants away from the border....
articles.abstract: In some of the most intense ground clashes so far, Israeli troops and Hezbollah militants fought fiercely Monday in and around two hilltop towns in southern Lebanon where the Israeli military is seeking to drive the militants away from the border.     The main battle was on the outskirts of Bint Jbail, about two miles across the border into Lebanon, where 2 Israeli soldiers were killed and 14 wounded, the Israeli military said. Hezbollah fighters were believed to have sustained a greater number of casualties, the military added, though it did not have figures.
articles.lead_paragraph: AVIVIM, Israel, July 24 - In some of the most intense ground clashes so far, Israeli troops and Hezbollah militants fought fiercely Monday in and around two hilltop towns in southern Lebanon where the Israeli military is seeking to drive the militants away from the border.
articles.byline: By Craig S. Smith and Greg Myre
